Axon

Amply experienced in redistribution of medical publications and material, Axon wants to redesign their website to stop their traditional users from using other online options.

UX Challenges

Axon users have grown accustomed to a hard, unfriendly purchase process through the Client's 90s site. Their loyalty can only last for so long: and they're actually fleeing to other distributors that are less connected to the world of medicine, but bigger, faster and easy-to-use. Our goal is kind of simple:{" "} Axon needs to be easy to use and transmit trustworthiness .

A redesign might be the chance to do just that. I take the opportunity to revisit the site's information organization, the conversion process and the look and feel of the whole Axon experience.

UX Solutions

The UX strategy rests on a single hypothesis: the users will stay with a smaller distributor{" "} if he can find the product easily. From that, we set three main goals. First and most important,{" "} a uniform experience throughout the site. Second, a proficient and ever-present search. And lastly, a personal profile that will allow the site to customize product display.

Long story short, the users find themselves abducted by aliens and are asked to compete in a driving competition. They'll drive through the map until the finish line, answering questions and beating aliens left and right.

There are two rankings to feed the user's competitive drive: an in-app ranking against a series of imaginary characters and one against the user's contacts who are using the app. As the users advance in the map, they unlock goals that will get them stickers for their user-zone car.

); } }
